questions.text: What type of fracture is caused by a hammer?
questions.explanation:
Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

 

Depressed fracture

 

Comminuted fracture

Gutter fracture

Ring Fracture

(Option D)

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option C)
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.



 

Ring fracture

 

Hinge fracture

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

(Option A)

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

 

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

Diastatic Fracture

questions.text: A dead body was found with a wound on the neck, with clean-cut edges, crushed tissues along with the disruption of the vertebral bones.Identify the type of wound.
A 12-year-old boy presents with an injury sustained during a football match after being tackled by an opponent. As the casualty medical officer, how would you describe the wound in the case sheet?
questions.explanation:
Stellate

Round objects (e.g., hammer).

Crescentic

Objects with edges.

Linear

Long, thin objects (e.g., pipes)

Irregular/Y-shaped

Flat-surfaced objects

Accidental

Found on exposed body parts.

Homicidal

Found on non-accessible areas, typically the head.

Suicidal

Rare, usually on exposed parts, on the same side of the body.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was brought to the ER after an assault with a sharp axe. Identify the type of wound.
questions.explanation:
Chop wounds/ Slash wounds

  • These are deep gaping wounds inflicted by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon when applied with significant force.
  • It is a combination of blunt and sharp force injury.

Weapons used

  • Hatchet
  • Axe
  • Sword
  • Broad heavy knife
  • Chopper
  • Saber
  • Meat cleaver

Features of the wound
  • The axe's lower end (heel) strikes first, leaving a deeper wound than the upper end (toe).
  • It is an incised wound on skin with an underlying communited fracture or deep grove in the bone.
  • Dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating blade.
  • Margins are sharp and may have abrasions, bruising, and some lacerations with severe injury to underlying organs.

Medicolegal importance

  • Most injuries are homicidal.
  • Frew are accidental by machinery (propeller injuries).
  • Rarely suicidal.
  • Wounds give details of the weapon used and the direction of attack.

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Sweating

Condition

Cause

Clinical Features

Postmortem Findings

Heat Stroke

 

 

Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure
  • Sudden collapse-loss of consciousness, due to hypotension (Option B)
  • Skin hot, initially wet, then dry (Option A)
  • Hyperventilation- tachycardia
  • Core temp > 40.5°C/104 F
  • Pupils contracted
  • Convulsions
  • Unconsciousness
  • Cerebral dysfunction (Option D)
  • High fever
  • Absence of sweating (Option C)
  • Congested lungs, intrathoracic petechiae (children)
  • Subendocardial hemorrhages
  • Brain congestion, flattened convolutions, petechiae in the 3rd/4th ventricle walls

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Incised looking laceration

Types of Laceration

 

Split Laceration (Incised looking laceration)
  • These occur when skin is crushed between two objects, such as the scalp being compressed between the skull and a hard surface like the ground or a blunt object.
  • Seen on areas where the skin is close to bone, with minimal underlying tissue
  • E.g., scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, jaw, iliac crest, perineum, shin.
  • Lacerations without excessive skin crushing can have sharp edges, resembling incised wounds.
  • Also known as incised looking laceration.
  • These are not undermined and show tissue bridges.

Avulsion (Shearing Laceration)

 
  • Caused by a shearing force at an acute angle, detaching skin or organs from their attachments.
  • The shearing and grinding force from a heavy object, like a lorry wheel passing over a limb, can cause the skin to separate from the underlying tissues, a condition known as avulsion or "flaying."
  • This often results in crushed muscles and fractured bones. The detached skin may have extensive abrasions due to the tyre’s friction, but one portion is still in continuity with adjacent skin.
  • Lacerations from shearing forces can leave the skin intact while separating the underlying soft tissue from the fascia, resulting in a blood-filled pocket. This type of injury is often observed on the back of the thighs in pedestrians hit by motor vehicles.

questions.text: Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.explanation:
Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option B)

Ring Fracture

(Option D ruled out)
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.

Often caused by side impacts.


 

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Hinge fracture

Ring fracture

Depressed Fracture (Option A ruled out)
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.(Option C ruled out)

Depressed fracture

questions.text: Identify the injury the image below :
questions.explanation:
Scratch Abrasion (Linear Abrasion)

Grazed Abrasion (Sliding Abrasion)

Mechanism: Caused by tangential (side-to-side) force, producing a long and narrow abrasion.

Features: Linear in nature, with length being more significant than width.

Examples: Fingernail abrasion, thorn abrasion, and pin abrasion.


 

Mechanism: Occurs when skin slides over a rough surface, resulting in superficial scrapes.

Also Known As: Grinding abrasion, gravel rash, brush-burn.

Features: Seen in road traffic accidents or falls, especially on exposed areas like knees or elbows.

Imprint Abrasion (Patterned Abrasion)

Pressure Abrasion (Crushing Abrasion)

Mechanism: Results from compressive force applied perpendicular to the skin, leaving a distinct pattern of the object.

Also Known As Impact abrasion, contact abrasion, patterned abrasion.

Examples: Tyre marks, bite marks

 

Mechanism: Caused by a continuous vertical force applied to the skin, crushing the epidermis.

Features: Deeper skin injuries are often seen with prolonged pressure, potentially leading to necrosis.

Examples: Ligature marks in hanging or strangulation

Multiple Lines
  • Indicate the endpoint of the abrasion.
  • Reflect the direction of the applied force.

Uneven and Longitudinal Lines
  • Show irregularity at the end of the abrasion.
  • Suggest pulling or scraping of the skin.

Heaped-up or Aggregated Lines
  • Also known as Epithelial tags (Terminal tags)
  • Skin tissues dragged opposite to the force direction.
  • Point toward the end of the abrasion, indicating the force direction
  • (e.g., tags heaped at the right end, if the force was left to right).

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.explanation:
Hypothermia

Definition

Core temperature below 36°C (96.8°F)

Signs
  • Disorientation
  • Dulling of consciousness
  • Loss of reflex
  • Fall in respiration, heart rate, and blood pressure
  • Red patches and pallor of the skin
  • Edema of the face
  • Stiffness of neck muscles

Autopsy findings
  • Patches of pink to brownish-pink discoloration
  • Postmortem staining: Pink/bright red
  • Cyanosis or pallor in extremities ("white deaths")
  • Edema of feet and blistering of skin
  • Stomach: Wischnewsky spots-brownish black colored gastric mucosal ulcers
  • Viscera-congested, hemorrhagic

Phenomena seen in hypothermia victims

  • Paradoxical undressing- found undressed due to disorientation which increases heat loss (mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide)
  • ‘Hide and die' syndrome- found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery)
  • Chilblain (Erythema Pernio)- red, itching skin lesions typically found on extremities due to cold exposure, often accompanied by edema and blistering.

questions.text: Post-mortem examination reveals specific findings. What is this finding known as?
The image provided shows a wound. What type of wound is it?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ Medicolegal importance of bruises:
  • ➤ Medicolegal importance of bruises:
  • ➤ Reexamination after 24 hours is advisable as the bruises appear clearly by this time. Age of injury is determined by color changes. The degree of violence is evaluated by their size. Patterned bruises give details about the object/weapon used . A bruise is grievous when the internal organs are affected. Fabricated bruises are used to falsely accuse someone or in defense of a crime. Postmortem staining should be differentiated from a bruise. Character and manner of injury may be known from the distribution of bruises (six penny bruises from the force of fingertips).
  • ➤ Reexamination after 24 hours is advisable as the bruises appear clearly by this time.
  • ➤ Age of injury is determined by color changes.
  • ➤ The degree of violence is evaluated by their size.
  • ➤ The degree of violence
  • ➤ Patterned bruises give details about the object/weapon used .
  • ➤ object/weapon used
  • ➤ A bruise is grievous when the internal organs are affected.
  • ➤ Fabricated bruises are used to falsely accuse someone or in defense of a crime.
  • ➤ Fabricated bruises
  • ➤ Postmortem staining should be differentiated from a bruise.
  • ➤ Character and manner of injury may be known from the distribution of bruises (six penny bruises from the force of fingertips).
  • ➤ Character and manner of injury

Mechanism of injury of contusions

  • A contusion or bruise is a leak of blood into the tissues due to the rupture of blood vessels (veins, venules, arterioles) caused due to injury by a blunt object.
  • Some blunt objects that can cause contusions are fist, stones, sticks, bar, whip, hammer, axe, wooden handle, poker, foot with shoe or boot, etc.

Factors influencing the formation of bruises

Condition and type of tissues
  • Vascular and loose tissues may form large bruises even with a small degree of violence.
    • Examples: face, vulva, and scrotum.
  • Firm fibrous tissues, strongly supported tissues, and those covered by a thick dermis produce a comparatively small bruise for moderate trauma.
    • Examples: abdomen, back, scalp, palms, and soles.
  • Injury of tissues over bony surfaces shows prominent bruising.

Age

  • Children bruise easily.
  • Older people bruise easily.

Gender

  • Women bruise more easily than men.
  • Obese people bruise easily due to the high volume of subcutaneous tissue.

Colour of the skin

  • Bruising is more easily visible in fair-skinned people than in dark-skinned people.
  • Contusions are better felt in dark-skinned people than seen.

Natural diseases

  • Prominent bruising is seen with minor trauma in patients with:
    • Arteriosclerosis
    • Whooping cough in children due to violent coughing can cause bruising
    • Purpura hemorrhagica
    • Leukemia
    • Hemophilia
    • Scurvy
    • Vitamin K
    • Prothrombin deficiency
    • Phosphorus poisoning
    • Older persons on systemic steroids

Gravity shifting of the blood

  • In deep bruises, blood tracks along the fascial planes and may cause the bruise at a different site.
  • This is called ectopic bruising or percolated or migratory contusion.
  • Examples:
    • Spectacle hematoma or black eye in blunt trauma to the forehead.
    • Bruise behind ear due to basal skull fracture (Battle’s sign).
    • Bruise in the neck from fracture of the jaw.
    • Bruise around the ankle from a kick on the calf.

questions.text: Which of the following injuries is not expected in a person brought to the hospital with a history of a road traffic accident (RTA)?
The dead body of a 30-year-old male drowning victim was brought in for autopsy. Upon examination, multiple cuts were observed on the victim's arm. What finding is likely to be seen in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Defense wou

questions.text: A person got stabbed in his anterior thigh and died. His body was brought for postmortem. What type of injury is this?
questions.explanation:
Stab wound/Punctured wound

These are inflicted by penetration with long, narrow instruments having pointed (sometimes blunt) ends into the depth of the body, which is deeper than its length and width.

Weapons used

  • Knife (most common)
  • Pieces of glass (broken glass bottle)
  • Scissors
  • Screwdrivers
  • Pens
  • Ice picks
  • Forks

Types of stab wounds

  • Puncture wound: (Option C)
    • Soft tissues are involved
  • Penetrating wound:
    • Enters a body cavity or a viscus
  • Perforating wound:
    • Through-and-through puncture wounds
    • The weapon enters the body from one side and comes out the other
    • The wound of entry is larger than the exit

Significance of the wound dimensions

  • Length is slightly less than the width of the weapon due to the stretching of the skin.
  • Breadth is more than the thickness of weapon due to gaping.
  • Depth, the greatest dimension of the wound, corresponds to the length of the weapon's blade, which has completely entered the body without perforation.
  • Margins or edges of the wound are clean cut with usually no abrasion or bruising.
    • Margins by a pointed or conical weapon have lacerated edges
    • If the hilt guard of the weapon strikes the skin, a regular, sharp, and well-defined patterned abrasion or bruising is formed

questions.text: Leading questions can be asked in?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Examination-in-Chief (Direct Examination)

Cross-Examination

Re-Examination

Conducted By

Party who calls the witness (e.g., public prosecutor)

Opposing party (typically defense)

Party who called the witness

Purpose
  • Present all relevant facts
  • Provide expert interpretation if applicable
  • Challenge witness's credibility
  • Elicit favorable facts
  • Test accuracy

Clarify issues raised during cross-examination

Leading Questions

Not allowed unless the witness is declared hostile (Option D)

Allowed (Sec. 146 BSA)

Not allowed (Option B)

Nature of Questions

Open-ended questions to elicit narrative

Can include leading questions to control the narrative

Generally clarifying questions

Time Limit

Typically structured and may have time constraints

No set time limit; may last for hours or even days

Generally limited to clarification purposes

Judicial Oversight

Judge may intervene to ensure questions are relevant and not leading

Court can disallow indecent or scandalous questions (Sec. 154, BSA)

Judge monitors to ensure focus remains on clarification

questions.text: Which of the following is the bleeding vessel in extradural hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Space and Hemorrhages

Location

Blood vessel involved

Epidural Space/ Hemorrhage

Between the skull vault and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to epidural hematoma.

Middle meningeal artery

(Option A)

Subdural Space/ Hemorrhage

Between the arachnoid and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to subdural hematoma.

Bridging veins (which drain into the dural venous sinus)

(Option B ruled out)

Subarachnoid Space/ Hemorrhage

Between the arachnoid and pia mater

Arteries of the circle of Willis (Middle cerebral artery, Anterior communicating artery -most commonly) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: During measurement of a rifled barrel weapon, the caliber depends on?
questions.correct_answer: A. Distance between two opposite lands

questions.text: Most common organ involved in seat-belt injury is?
questions.explanation:
Patterned contusion (known as Seat belt sign)
  • Drivers: starts from the right shoulder
  • Passengers: starts from the left shoulder

Intra-abdominal (deceleration- compression)
  • Mesentery - most commonly affected (Option D)
  • Small intestine: DJ flexure (primary),Ileocaecal junction (secondary)
  • Liver, Spleen, Pancreas(Option A, B and C)

Vertebral injuries (distraction- compression)
  • Distraction(separation of joint): seen on posterior side
  • Compression: seen on anterior side
  • Chance fracture: fracture involving all 3 columns of spine

Seat belt syndrome
  • Seat belt sign + intra-abdominal injuries + vertebral injuries

questions.text: The most common organ injuries in air blast shock waves will be?
questions.explanation:
Air Blast Injuries

Underwater Blast Injuries

Most commonly injured:

Tympanic membrane (ear) - Rupture and middle ear damage are common
  • Tympanic membrane (ear) - More likely to occur when the head is submerged.
  • Gastrointestinal tract - When the head is not submerged.

Most severely injured:

Lungs - Blast lung injury is a common cause of delayed mortality and can cause pulmonary contusion, air embolism, and other damage

Gastrointestinal tract - Underwater blasts can cause more severe GI injuries due to pressure effects on hollow organs

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault , you notice a wound with ragged, irregular and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical swallowtails. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs . You would document this wound as a/an.
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Lacerated wou

questions.text: Which of the following is true about exhumation?

options.label: A
options.text: The executive magistrate can order for exhumation

options.label: C
options.text: Postmortem can be done on exhumated body

questions.correct_answer: A. The executive magistrate can order for exhumation
questions.explanation:
Definition Exhumation is the process of digging up and removing a buried body from its place of interment (burial) for various reasons, including legal, forensic, medical, or historical purposes.
Legal Grounds Exhumations can occur for legal reasons, such as when an autopsy or forensic investigation is required, or when a court order is issued for reburial elsewhere.
Forensic Exhumation In forensic contexts, exhumation is often performed to gather evidence in cases of suspected foul play, to identify unknown remains, or to reevaluate the cause of death.
Medical Examination Exhumations for medical purposes can be carried out to perform post-mortem examinations, assess the progression of diseases, or conduct genetic testing for familial diseases.

questions.text: During the examination of injury, hair bulbs are noted to be crushed. The probable type of wound is:
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - L

questions.text: In alleged history of gunshot injury , there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound . The injury is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Close shot entry wou

Gunshot Injury Range

Proximity of Firearm to Body

Characteristics

Contact Range

Muzzle in direct contact

  • Burning, blackening, and tattooing around entry wound

  • Irregular or stellate appearance for exit wounds

Close Range

Muzzle in close proximity

  • Burning, blackening, and tattooing around entry wound

  • Exit wounds may exhibit irregular or stellate appearance

Near Range

Short distance from body

  • Less pronounced effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing

  • Entry and exit wounds may show some characteristics of contact or close-range injuries

Distant Range

Significant distance

  • Absent or minimal effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing

  • Smaller, circular or oval-shaped entry and exit wounds

questions.correct_answer: A. Residual from barrel of gun

questions.text: Name the type of skull fracture .
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Hinge fractu

Type of Skull Vault Fracture

Radiological Findings

Diastatic Fracture

Widening of the sutures due to separation of cranial bones

Stellate Fracture

Fracture lines radiating from a central point

Basilar Skull Fracture

Fracture involving the base of the skull

Le Fort Fracture

Fracture involving the maxilla and facial skeleton

Ping-Pong Fracture

Impacted fracture with inward and outward depression

questions.text: Identify the injury the image below :
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - A

Type of Injury

Characteristic Features

Abrasion

Superficial, scraping or rubbing injury that removes the superficial layers of skin. Irregular shape, reddish or pinkish color.

Laceration

Deep cut or tear in the skin and underlying tissues. Irregular or clean edges, may require suturing or medical intervention.

Contusion

A contusion is a bruising of the skin or underlying tissues due to blunt force trauma. May result in pain, swelling, and discoloration.

Incision

Clean, intentional cut made with a sharp object. Straight edges, controlled bleeding, may require suturing or medical intervention.
